rows.title: Power of three

transcript.eng:
Close your eyes.
Let's use the magic power of 3 to stay present and relax. 

Name 3 sounds you can hear right now.
Name 3 smells you can smell right now.
Name your 3 favourite foods.
What are 3 things you can be gratefful for right now.

At the end of a touch day, thinking of 3 things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.

rows.transcript:

text_1.eng: Self-care is a key parenting tool. It starts with recognising how we feel.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great. And amazing that you are using this app – it shows your commitment as a parent. Make sure you give yourself credit and praise for what you are doing.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Every day has its highs and lows. Praise yourself for being here and trying – you are moving forward.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry that things are difficult right now. Take a deep breath and know that you are valued.

rows.text_1: Self-care is a key parenting tool. It starts with recognising how we feel.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Great. And amazing that you are using this app – it shows your commitment as a parent. Make sure you give yourself credit and praise for what you are doing.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Every day has its highs and lows. Praise yourself for being here and trying – you are moving forward.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Sorry that things are difficult right now. Take a deep breath and know that you are valued.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's lesson is about helping our children follow instructions and rules by using consequences

Consequences are the results of actions and behaviours. Parents can use a planned consequence when children don’t follow a rule or instruction. 

For example if a child doesn’t follow the rule to come home from playing at 6pm, then a consequence could be that the child can’t go out to play the next day. 

Giving clear consequences teaches children that their actions affect themselves and others.

media_title.eng: How can calm consequences help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings everyone.

Even if you do everything right, your child will misbehave sometimes. We may be tempted to scream and shout, but that just leaves everyone more angry. 

If we stay calm, and give them a calm consequence, they will learn to take responsibility for their actions instead.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's lesson is about helping our children follow instructions and rules by using consequences

Consequences are the results of actions and behaviours. Parents can use a planned consequence when children don’t follow a rule or instruction. 

For example if a child doesn’t follow the rule to come home from playing at 6pm, then a consequence could be that the child can’t go out to play the next day. 

Giving clear consequences teaches children that their actions affect themselves and others.
rows.media_title: How can calm consequences help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings everyone.

Even if you do everything right, your child will misbehave sometimes. We may be tempted to scream and shout, but that just leaves everyone more angry. 

If we stay calm, and give them a calm consequence, they will learn to take responsibility for their actions instead.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Some consequences happen naturally — like when a toy breaks, it can’t be used.

Others you set to help your child follow rules (if you do not pack away your toys, you won’t be allowed to play with them tomorrow).

Let’s see how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name uses consequences to help his nephew, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, follow instructions:

character_1_text.eng: You are playing so nice and quiet, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to clean up your toys.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Some consequences happen naturally — like when a toy breaks, it can’t be used.

Others you set to help your child follow rules (if you do not pack away your toys, you won’t be allowed to play with them tomorrow).

Let’s see how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name uses consequences to help his nephew, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, follow instructions:
rows.character_1_text: You are playing so nice and quiet, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to clean up your toys.

character_1_text.eng: It’s time to put away your toys

rows.character_1_text: It’s time to put away your toys

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, either you put away the toys now, or you won’t be able to play with your toys after dinner.

character_2_text.eng: No @data.characters.f3_uncle.role_name! I don’t want to! I’m not finished with my game.

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, either you put away the toys now, or you won’t be able to play with your toys after dinner.
rows.character_2_text: No @data.characters.f3_uncle.role_name! I don’t want to! I’m not finished with my game.

character_1_text.eng: Because you did not clean up your toys when I asked you to, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, you cannot play with your toys after dinner. Now please come and wash your hands.

rows.character_1_text: Because you did not clean up your toys when I asked you to, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, you cannot play with your toys after dinner. Now please come and wash your hands.

character_1_text.eng: Good job washing your hands so well, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name.

rows.character_1_text: Good job washing your hands so well, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name used a consequence here.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Because @data.characters.f3_son_4.name didn't put his toys away even after being given a consequence

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Yes! Using a consequence in this situation is a good way to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn to make decisions.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Because he already tried yelling, and it didn’t work

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f3_uncle.name explains the consequence in a calm way.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: He speaks in a calm, firm way, explains why he is giving a consequence, and connects the consequence to the behaviour

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng:
That’s right. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it’s important to introduce consequences when you are feeling calm and makes sure that @data.characters.f3_son_4.name understands why he can’t play after dinner. 
There’s one more right answer hiding! Did you find it?

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: He gets a bit angry, but then makes the consequence clear.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng:
That’s right. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it’s important to follow-through for the consequence to work. 
There’s one more right answer hiding! Did you find it?

quiz_3_question.eng:
What would @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn if @data.characters.f3_uncle.name gives in or does not give the consequence? 

@data.characters.f3_son_4.name would learn:

quiz_3_option_1_text.eng: He can get away with this behaviour in the future

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.

quiz_3_option_2_text.eng: Not to take @data.characters.f3_uncle.name seriously in the future when he gives an instruction

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.

quiz_3_option_3_text.eng: That @data.characters.f3_uncle.name loves him and forgives him

quiz_3_feedback_3.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f3_son_4.name would actually learn not to take @data.characters.f3_uncle.name seriously when he gives an instruction, or that he can get away with this behaviour in the future.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Yes! Using a consequence in this situation is a good way to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn to make decisions.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: Because @data.characters.f3_son_4.name didn't put his toys away even after being given a consequence
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: Because he already tried yelling, and it didn’t work

rows.quiz_2_option_2_text: He speaks in a calm, firm way, explains why he is giving a consequence, and connects the consequence to the behaviour
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2:
That’s right. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it’s important to introduce consequences when you are feeling calm and makes sure that @data.characters.f3_son_4.name understands why he can’t play after dinner. 
There’s one more right answer hiding! Did you find it?
rows.quiz_2_option_3_text: He gets a bit angry, but then makes the consequence clear.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_4:
That’s right. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it’s important to follow-through for the consequence to work. 
There’s one more right answer hiding! Did you find it?

What would @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn if @data.characters.f3_uncle.name gives in or does not give the consequence? 

@data.characters.f3_son_4.name would learn:
rows.quiz_3_option_1_text: He can get away with this behaviour in the future
rows.quiz_3_feedback_1: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.
rows.quiz_3_option_2_text: Not to take @data.characters.f3_uncle.name seriously in the future when he gives an instruction
rows.quiz_3_feedback_2: Exactly. It is really important to follow through with what we say, so our children learn boundaries and know they can trust our word.
rows.quiz_3_option_3_text: That @data.characters.f3_uncle.name loves him and forgives him
rows.quiz_3_feedback_3: Try again! @data.characters.f3_son_4.name would actually learn not to take @data.characters.f3_uncle.name seriously when he gives an instruction, or that he can get away with this behaviour in the future.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some easy steps to use consequences when your child misbehaves.

section_1_text.eng:
Take some deep breaths or walk away from the situation if you need to.

Then, respond in a calm, clear way.

section_1_extra_text.eng: Shouting at our children only makes things worse. It also teaches them that it is okay to treat others like this when they are upset.

section_2_text.eng:
Before giving a consequence, give your child the choice to behave and time to do what you asked.

Give a consequence connected to the behaviour, and make sure it is something you can follow through with.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
For example, if they do not clean up their toys, they cannot play with them the next day (rather than the whole week).

If your child is experiencing a natural consequence for their action already (like not being able to play with their toy after breaking it), you might not need to give them an additional consequence.

section_3_text.eng:
It is important to follow through with consequences for the rules you have set, every time your children do not follow them.

This helps your child know what to expect, and makes it more likely that they will follow the rule.

section_3_extra_text.eng: Talk about consequences for breaking household rules when you create these rules, so that your child knows them and sticks to them.

section_4_text.eng: Involve your children in planning consequences for certain behaviours.

section_4_extra_text.eng: Talk about what the consequence could be if a rule isn’t followed while you’re involving your child in the planning.

For example, if they do not clean up their toys, they cannot play with them the next day (rather than the whole week).

text_1_facilitator.eng: Now that we have learned a few useful tips, let’s come up with some ideas for reasonable and realistic consequences.

quiz_1_question.eng: Would any of these consequences be helpful for you and your child?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: If you are late for dinner, your food will be cold

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: If you continue splashing water out of the bath, bath time will be over

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: If you break your toy, you will have no toy to play with

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: If you can’t play close to home where I can see you, then you will have to come inside

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out together.

quiz_1_option_5_text.eng: If you do not put away your toys, then you cannot play with them tomorrow morning

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Great. Discuss this (or another) consequence with your child and family, and try it out tomorrow.

quiz_1_option_6_text.eng: None of these will work in my home

quiz_1_feedback_6.eng: That's okay! Try to think of just one consequence that you feel confident you can follow-through with in a calm way. Try starting with something small.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Remember that praising your child for the things you would like them to keep doing is a good way to see more positive behaviour in your home. 

Using fair and realistic consequences is also part of building a positive relationship with your child.

Your home activity is to have a discussion with your child about one persistent challenging household rule and discuss a possible consequence.

media_title.eng: Agreeing on consequences together works! Tap play to hear @data.characters.media_female_13.name tell her story

quiz_1_question.eng: The next time your child cannot follow instructions, can you use a fair consequence in a calm way?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Keep trying. It will get easier in time. You can start by considering smaller behaviours that your child struggles with and planning a fair consequence in advance so you're ready. Remember to take a pause to calm down before you respond.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's great! Don't forget to take a pause before you give the consequence so that you're able to remain calm and praise yourself afterwards for a job well done!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That's okay. Keep trying. It will get easier in time. You can start by considering smaller behaviours that your child struggles with and planning a fair consequence in advance so you're ready. Remember to take a pause to calm down before you respond.
rows.quiz_1_question: The next time your child cannot follow instructions, can you use a fair consequence in a calm way?
rows.text_1_facilitator:
Remember that praising your child for the things you would like them to keep doing is a good way to see more positive behaviour in your home. 

Using fair and realistic consequences is also part of building a positive relationship with your child.

Your home activity is to have a discussion with your child about one persistent challenging household rule and discuss a possible consequence.
